result.hateful_meaning: From German language negative word nichts/nix (nothing) and -manni for 'man'. Rarely used.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of fair complexion or with blond or red hair
A person of German descent.
A person of German descent.

Doryphore means Colorado potato beetle in French. This term was used during World War II, but is less common than Boche, Fritz or Frisés. It refers to the fact that the Germans during the Occupation took large part of the production of France's agriculture and industry.
heretic
Person of Middle Eastern descent.
[1] A prostitute. [2] A woman of loose morals. [3] A despicable person or thing (as in the phrase "pute de...")
[1] A prostitute. [2] A woman of loose morals. [3] A despicable person or thing (as in the phrase "pute de...")
A corrupt, debauched, or treacherous woman; a woman with loose morals. Generally carries sexual connotations.
A non-Thai person.
A person of Irish descent.
A person in the Netherlands, which is 20% below sea level.
Italian word for a black person, from 'melanzane' (meaning eggplant).
Used by loyalists in Northern Ireland for members of the nationalist/Catholic/Gaelic community. Derived the Irish name Tadhg, often mistransliterated as Timothy.
Used by poor rural people to denote those of lower status than themselves, particularly those who commit incest (jumping the family tree).
A Jewish person (first used in the 1930s).
A non-Jewish man, especially one perceived to be anti-Semitic.
An Ashkenazi Jew. From kikel, Yiddish for 'circle'. Illiterate immigrant Jews signed legal documents with an 'O' (similar to an 'X').
A Native American.
In Bangladesh and West Bengal, denotes a Muslim. From Bengali nere meaning bald, referring to the Buddhist ancestors of Muslims in Bengal.
Derogatory word for Tutsis in the Congo, from 'penis' or 'thing'.
Derogatory word for Rwandans, from a local plant considered useless or treacherous
[1] Uncircumcised. [2] Pagan.
An uncultivated Australian.
Used by Greeks when referring to the Macedonians in an attempt to deny self-identification
A non-Thai person.
A person of Hispanic descent.
"Vietnamese person" in Khmer. Considered derogatory.
Chicano slur for Mexicans used in Los Angeles, from use of hairnets.

[1] Australian aboriginal. Boong, pronounced with (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning dead; infected; or dysfunctional. From bung, to go bung 'Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]'. Highly offensive. [2] In New Zealand, a Pacific Islander.
A black person. Used in the novel 'To Kill a Mockingbird'.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of fair complexion or with blond or red hair
An Italian-American male. Derives from the Italian given name, Guido. Used mostly in the Northeastern United States as a stereotype for working-class urban Italian-Americans.
A person of common or low class Irish ancestry.
In Australia, Aboriginal pejorative term for white people.
A black person. Derived from 'negroid'.
A Muslim.

A female Native American. Derived from lower East Coast Algonquian (Massachuset: ussqua), which originally meant 'young woman', but which took on strong negative connotations in the late 20th century.
Somali slur for a member of the Kikuyu community, meaning 'thief'.
Laborer-class whites in Barbados.
A black person.
A Pole or a person of Polish or Slavic origin, from the Polish endonym, Polak (see Name of Poland).
A person of perceived Chinese or East Asian descent. An offensive term that has raised considerable controversy, for example when used by comedian Rosie O'Donnell.
An Anglo-Indian or Eurasian half-caste [probably from Hindi chi-chi fie!, literally, dirt] Also can refer to English spoken with a Southwest Asian accent.
Italian word for a black person, from 'melanzane' (meaning eggplant).
Embu slur for a member of the Luo ethnic group, meaning 'uncircumcised'.
A black person, from the character on The Little Rascals.

An Italian, Spaniard or Portuguese person, possibly derived from the Spanish name, 'Diego,' a corruption of the title Hidalgo (member of the Gentry, from Spanish > hijo de algo 'son of someone [important]' or the Sardinian language first person pronoun, dego)t.
Historical Native American term for Caucasian.
A person of Hawaiian descent.
A person of German descent, from 'Nazi'.
A Roman Catholic person, usually Irish Catholic.

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.
A person of Arabic descent, from Aladdin and his magic carpet.
A German (shortened from the French term caboche dure 'hard head' or 'stubborn').
A person of common or low class Irish ancestry.
Literally Hun. Derogatory, containing allusions to Lapland War and sack of Lapland. Rarely used, today rather influenced by the English usage.
Used by loyalists in Northern Ireland for members of the nationalist/Catholic/Gaelic community. Derived the Irish name Tadhg, often mistransliterated as Timothy.

A black person, especially a black child. More commonly used in states where alligators are found, particularly Florida. First used in the early 20th century, although some hypothesize the term originated in the late 19th century.
A Serbian living in Austria or Germany.
Embu slur for a member of the Luo ethnic group, meaning 'uncircumcised'.

A black person. The term may cause offense. though Randall Kennedy's Nigger: The Strange Career of a Troublesome Word notes that some judges have considered 'darky' a 'term of endearment.' In South Africa, it can be considered offensive (depending on the context), but is commonly used among black people to refer to other black people in a non-derogatory way.
A black Canadian.

Used by the Sinhala majority to refer to a person of Muslim origin. The literal meaning of 'Thambi' is younger brother (in Tamil), Originally, this must have been used not as an offensive term but an affectionate one.
A poor or disenfranchised person of Irish descent.

A Scottish person. Scots language nickname for the personal name John, cognate to the English, Jack. Occasionally used by the English as an insult. but also in respectful reference to elite Scottish, particularly Highland troops, e.g. the 9th (Scottish) Division. Same vein as the English insult for the French, as Frogs.
Used by the Sinhala/Tamil majority to refer to a person of Muslim origin hailing from East of the island (Ampara, Pothuvil, Madakalapuwa area).
lesbian
a person without an arm or a leg
prostitute
old person
In the UK, a promiscuous woman
result.nonhateful_meaning: Waste matter, particularly as a result of incineration

result.hateful_meaning: In the UK, derogatory word for woman
In Ireland, a disreputable, working class or delinquent person
In Ireland, a disreputable, working class or delinquent person
[1] In Hawaii, an uneducated, lower class and/or ethnic Polynesian person. [2] In Ireland, a disreputable or lower class person.
In Ireland, a disreputable, working class or delinquent person
In Ireland, a disreputable or delinquent person
In the UK, a criminal dealing in counterfeit and/or stolen goods
A woman of loose morals
A woman of loose morals
In the UK, Australia or New Zealand, an unsophisticated, antisocial, drunken and/or lower class person
In the UK, Australia or New Zealand, an unsophisticated, antisocial, drunken and/or lower class person
In Scotland, an unsophisticated or lower class female
In Ireland, a disreputable, working class or delinquent person
A disreputable and/or working class person
A disreputable and/or working class person
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
A disreputable and/or working class person, from 'scallywag'
A disreputable and/or working class person, from 'scallywag'
In Scotland, a lower class person or criminal, often identified with public housing and a predilection for sportswear
In the UK, an unsophisticated or working class person with a predilection for ostentatious sportswear and jewellery

A French person, from the defeat of the French against the German in 1940, and the huge variety of cheeses originating from France. Gained popularity after the term was used on an episode of The Simpsons and was subsequently adopted by right-wing pundits. Rarely used today.
Pejorative term which is shortened from either transgendered, transsexual or transvestite. May be used to refer to these individuals, or others, in a derogatory or offensive manner.
